We ordered the Grand Shellfish Plateau and man, lemme tell you: sublime. After that I had the veal chop and I don't think I can have anything else.So, yes, the food is delicious, but what they really ought to do is rename this place: The Cougar Den. Along with my confidants I got eyed, clawed and sized up by several hungry cougars. Not that I have anything against cougars (in fact, I think another trip to this spot is in order) but the overwhelming supply of botox in that joint must have been an FDA violation.The waiters were lively, fun guys who had real suggestions to make. That's always a pleasant surprise. I have faith in a joint who's staff knows what's good and what's a little off that day. Next time, I'll order the catnip.

So far, I have only tried the drinks. I had a Pimm's Cup to go with the Brit Colonist feel, and it couldn't have been more perfect. Unless I wore my pith helmet and monocle, which I wouldn't put past me next time. I love the decor - - so warm and inviting, with pictures of Curious George types frolicking throughout. The elixers are well mixed and the vibe is so relaxed, you could easily lose track of an hour or a decade here.

I have had a regular weekend table at The Waverly Inn for almost three years now and have enjoyed it thoroughly. It's the best restaurant in NYC. You will not find a better combination of food, service, decor, atmosphere and clientele than The Wave. When I heard that the team of Graydon Carter, Ronald Perelman, Jeff Klein and Jeremy King were revamping the legendary Monkey Bar, I knew this was going to be some place very special. On Wednesday afternoon, I got a phone call from the Office of The Editor at Vanity Fair inviting me to a prime seating for Saturday night. It was quite an honor to be asked but well deserved I must admit. My friend Mala and I had tickets to the theater, so dinner at Monkey Bar would be a great finish to our night. Graydon and his team have given it a chic and classy makeover. The new Monkey Bar is, in a word, glamorous. It is definitely the grander, uptown sister to The Waverly Inn. It evokes memories of the posh Stork Club and El Morocco. Originally opened in 1936, this rejuvenated Midtown supper club is tucked away on the ground floor of the Hotel Elysee. Mr. Carter has preserved the Monkey Bar's famous murals by Charlie Wala, depicting monkeys with human features riding elephants and mixing up daiquiris. But the new boss has added his own artistic touches as well. There's a brand new Edward Sorel mural which, as of this review, is almost completely finished. It is similar to but larger than the one at Mr. Carter's Waverly Inn in Greenwich Village, but with a more uptown cast of characters, including Fred Astaire, Duke Ellington, Mae West, and Babe Ruth. The bar holds 75 patrons and the dining room seats 150. The lobby to the restaurant has a formal reception desk and a spacious coat check room. To add to the exclusivity, all the seatings are pre-assigned. I met Brad, the gracious host, and he greeted us with a welcoming "We have been expecting you." There is only one entrance to the restaurant and it is akin to walking down the runway at Fashion Week. You are absolutely on display when you enter Monkey Bar. The restaurant has three tiered seating levels, all of which are lined with beautiful red leather banquettes, mirrored columns and bronze monkey themed lamps. The perimeter along the walls offers the largest banquettes with the best view of the restaurant. If you are seated in any of these you can just about see everyone without turning your head. There are a few columns that might obstruct your view, but not too much so. The lowest level known as "The Pit" is just as plush and offers the best view of the entrance staircase. It would also make a great ballroom dance floor for special occasions. The lighting is perfect and everyone glows in soothing amber light. The servers are attired in snow white-vintage style waiter jackets and their professionalism is fine tuned and attentive. My only concern is that the noise level was a bit loud especially considering the restaurant was only about one third full. The acoustics in the room are very strong and I am wary over what it may be like with this place filled. Mr. Carter has replaced Chef Elliott Ketley (Soho House, Le Caprice) with Chef Larry Forgione (An American Place) to helm the kitchen and he puts out some of the best high-end comfort classic dishes I have tasted since..well..John DeLucie's menu at The Waverly Inn. There is a wide range of selections to choose from and all are carefully crafted. Soups include a minted pea and chicken vegetable. The Clams Casino I had were wonderfully juicy and savory. There are numerous choices of salads to sample. Mala enjoyed her herbally light salad of arugula and parmesan. Eggs are featured as well in the forms of a soft boiled duck egg with foie gras and rhubarb eggs with fine herbs. The main entrees are highlighted by a yummy Nora's Meatloaf (named after Nora Ephron) with creamed potatoes and mushroom gravy. The seared diver sea scallops with creamed corn and bacon and sichuan pepper-crusted salmon were perfectly cooked.  You can have your fill of great steaks, veal chops and a spot on Chicken Paillard. The wine list is very thorough and moderately priced. I was impressed to see an offering of a Finger Lakes Riesling; one of my personal favorites. The luxurious and stately bar offers Old School cocktails of which we tossed down a tasty Brandy Alexander and Grasshopper. The dessert menu is getting notoriety for its strawberry shortcake and the luxurious sticky toffee pudding which is a great choice for a guilty, late night treat to share with all. Just like the Waverly Inn, there is of course the "scene" factor. On this first visit, we had the honor of meeting and conversing with Chef Tom Colicchio (Craft, BRAVOs TOP CHEF), Chef Joey Campanaro (The Little Owl) and actresses Joan Collins and Elizabeth Hurley. Graydon, my friend, you and your partners have hit another "home run". The Monkey Bar will surely become a regular haunt for me. Dinner for two with drinks, tax, and tip was $185.
If you are not going for the scene, you are missing the point.  My full write-up is called "The Empire Strikes Back" at katemalay.com, I love direct feedback on what I write.  Thanks!

A greasy little tidbit I just learned and would like to share:  Nora's Meat loaf, which is on the menu at Monkey Bar, is named after Nora Ephron, the NY essay humorist who also brought us the screenplays  "You've Got Mail" and "When Harry Met Sally."  I am excited enough about this to go there just to order the savory namesake and decipher how it wormed its way into Nora's heart and stomach.  If only I could find some cabbage strudel!  (In one of her essays in "I Feel Bad About My Neck," she laments the loss of this delicious dish when an old New York UES German bakery closed.  She does find a deliciously similar option). SEEN ON:  "Sex and the City", Episodes 46 and 51 (she meets the jazz guy there)

Well, I went last night - it's open to the public.  The front bar area was a nice space - think dark, secret rendez-vous meeting kinda space.The room has been changed in that instead of the old Monkey Bar which was a little sleeker & more modern, it seems they've made it into a more old school, blue-blood, moneyed kinda space: the wood is still dark, the walls are now painted gold w/these animal scenes (monkeys, of course, zebras, etc) with dark monkey sconce carvings.  (Space seemed smaller to me too.)  The back dining area is layed out as described at eater, and the back area is much brighter than the front.  We sat at the booth in the front bar and a very nice waiter came over and when I asked for a cocktail list, he politely told me, "there is no cocktail list but they can make anything."I couldn't resist and I had to reply with a "really, ANY-thing?"  but I'm boring, I got a prosecco which was $12/glass - which is pretty average for NY in price.When I left, I quizzed the door man (who was very friendly) about the future door policy, to which he replied, "it's open to everyone."I looked at him & said, "EVERY-one?"  (I was doing a lot of repeating last night...huh?)  and he laughed and nodded.The eye candy (as far as extremely handsome men) was abundant last night, if this continues (please-oh-please) I may have to keep going there for a drink or two on a regular basis...We'll see.

This cutesy, famous, yuppie meat Market is great for a happy hour hob-nob or a quick trendy lunch.  Very pricey and just OK food.  Great decor and cute waitstaff/bartenders.  (But isn't that a requirement in Manhattan these days?)I'd go back.

Love the Monkey bar.  Especially if you are just getting off work or meeting friends getting off work.  You know the kind of getting off work vibe I am talking about.  Decor is really nice.   Great place for a date.  It is not loud and does not get overly crowded...at least when ever I was there it was not bad.  I highly recommend the Monkey Bar.

Bogart used to drink here, really? Well he probably didn't have a cell phone, because there's no reception. I always find that rather annoying, in this day and age? No reception?The drinks were ok, depending on who made them, they were either very strong or very weak. The menu was annoying and I refused to order from it. I'm sorry, $28 for lobster kung pao? Kung pao is never supposed to be more than $5, and should come in a Styrofoam container with fried rice and an egg roll. The meat should be of questionable quality, and the presentation should be lumped together at best. So, yeah. I would perhaps return for drinks, focusing on the bartender that made them well, but I'm still annoyed about the food.

We checked out the famous monkey bar  during our stay at Hotel Elysee.  The wall mural with monkey scenes in the bar area was sort of interesting.We also dined in the restaurant for dinner with friends.  Its food was sort of creative Asian fusion style but unfortunately not our type.

Proximity to the place where I earn my living AND the fact that this place has been around for 70 years (an ostensible anomaly among watering holes) - one star.Fulfilled the need for a stiff drink after a not-so-dreadful-but-totally-pointless 4-Hour CLE - one star.Not too crowded and allowed me to decompress with good friends - one star. Rating justified.**Disclaimer: Drinks Only**

This bar is practically hidden!  You could walk right pass it without noticing. I went there because the bartender is a friend of my friends. The atmosphere is laid back - allows for conversations. I really liked the bowl of crunchies (a mix of peanuts with various crisp) that they served complimentary.And i highly recommend the mango mojito. I really want to like Monkey Bar.  The decor was wonderful, the lighting pleasantly low, the bar comfortable and inviting.But the bartender was having a hard time.  I heard him complain to a co worker that there should be two bartenders working.  No, if you could figure out how to pour a drink efficiently then you would have no problem.  Searching the bar for certain liquors instead of instictively reaching for them.  Making drinks one at a time instead of lining them up.  Making and carrying drinks to the server station 1 at a time instead of making 2 or 3 then making 1 trip across the bar.  Not putting tools like shakers, strainers, and muddler back in their proper spot so the next time you need it you don't have to search for it.  He had to be the most inefficient bartenders I have ever seen.It was actually kind of painful being a bar owner/manager and watching this poor kid struggle his way through what should have been an easy night.  He was nice enough.  Even offered me a drink on the house when he forgot he was running my credit card and left the card and receipt sitting on register for a good 5 minutes.And I wasn't the only one.  One of the servers had to come behind the bar several times to make her own drinks.  The young ladies sitting next to me sat for at least 10 minutes before he got their order.  He apologized profusely then proceeded to make other drinks before making theirs.5 stars for the ambiance and comfortable setting and for having Flor de Cana rum.  But, a 2 star knock down for having a practically incompetent bartender.

this is the kind of bar that I would describe as very discreet. it's the type of place that, for some reason, you will never bump into anyone you know (even though a hefty portion of the people i know are located within a 5 block radius of the monkey. if you are looking to have an affair, i would pick this place as the meetup spot for your dalliance. not that i can say this from experience, but certainly if i were asked to advise upon a proper location to commence a tryst, the monkey would be the spot. they have pretty good wines by the glass, and by the bottle, though i cannot comment on the price since i have never paid for myself while here.  the apps are good too-- a bit of a creative and fun bar menu. the decor is pretty cute-- there is a mural of various monkeys hanging around, monkeys that are not hearing/seeing/or speaking evil, and eating bananas (who knew!!)risk: one day you might have to pick up the tab herereward: nice calm atmosphere perfect for catching up with an "old friend"

The Monkey Bar is a bit small and dark, but it's generally uncrowded and the kind of place where you can actually have a conversation without screaming your lungs out.The appetizers may seem ridiculously expensive, but the servings are large and eminently shareable.
Very corporate, very dark, but a nice generally non-crowded spot for drinks.
